snippet: Wearing T-shirts that read “Black Lives Matter” and chanting “I can’t breathe,” demonstrators evoked memories of civil rights marches of the past.
abstract: Numerous protests take place around country in National Day of Resistance to commemorate deaths of black men at hands of police; march in Washington, known for years as the National March Against Police Violence, is attended by families of Michael Brown, Eric Garner, Akai Gurley and Tamir Rice, all unarmed men killed by police officers, and evokes civil rights marches of the past.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and ELENA SCHNEIDER
byline.contributor: Dan Glaun and Colin Moynihan contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Wearing T-shirts that read “Black Lives Matter” and chanting “I can’t breathe,” demonstrators evoked memories of civil rights marches of the past.

headline.main: Thousands March in Washington to Protest Police Violence
headline.print_headline: Thousands March During a Day of Protest Over Police Conduct
